name: Metabolism/Starvation
question1: Describe the physiology and biochemistry of fat, carbohydrate and protein metabolism
contents:
Carbohydrates are organic molecules made up of carbon, hydrogen and oxygen

  • They are consumed in the diet as either simple sugars (glucose or fructose) or complex sugars ( starch and cellulose).
  • Complex sugars are essentially simple sugars assembled into chains for ease of storage (eg starch from plants, glycogen from animals) or to form structures eg cellulose in plants)
  • Storage: Glycogen
  • Metabolism:
  • Glycolysis
  • Gluconeogenesis

( x2 acetyl CoA = 36 ATP's - ie, the output from glycolysis)


Triglycerides are the main constituent of body fat in animals and vegetables, and therefore in dietary fat.

  • They consist of three fatty acid molecules joined by a glycerol molecule
  • Absorption : Mixed micelles, free fatty acids, monoacylgylcerol, and cholesterols are absorbed via facilitated diffusion into the enterocyte
  • Storage: Fat is stored as triglycerides, and forms the bulk of energy storage of the body.
  • Triglycerides are synthesised by the LIVER
  • Metabolism: Free fatty acids can be:
  • absorbed by adiopocytes for storage, or be
  • Î²-oxidised to Acetyl CoA in the liver, which can enter the citric acid cycle to produce ATP.

( x6 acetyl CoA = 100 ATP's)


Protein metabolism

  • Essential amino acids cannot be produced by transamination - they must be supplied in the diet.
  • Metabolism :
  • Protein catabolism involves the deamination of amino acids.
  • Deamination can occur in one of two ways:
  • Oxidative deamination - hepatic deamination
  • Transamination - Amino group is transferred by aminotransferases to another amino acid or a ketoacid to produce:
  • Keto acids, which: enter the citric acid cycle and become ATP
  • Amino groups: enter the urea cycle and become urea.
question2: Explain the pathways (4) involved in metabolising a glucose load? How is glucose produced, how is it metabolised. How many ATP for pathways?
contents2:
Asked to draw the glycolysis pathway, how many ATP are produced


The main pathways of glucose metabolism are :

  • (1) Glycolysis (carbohydrates)
  • Describes the process of converting glucose (6C) into pyruvate (x2 3C)
  • This is known as the Embden-Meyerhof pathway.
  • Glucose-6-phosphate (ATP utilised to step to x2)
  • Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate (x2)
  • 1,3 Bis-phosphoglycerate (x2)
  • Pyruvate (x2) + 4 ATP
  • Occurs in the cytoplasm
  • Anaerobic - Does not consume oxygen or produce carbon dioxide
  • Output:
  • 2 ATP. (produces 4 / consumes 2)
  • 2 molecules of Pyruvate
  • Either enters:
  • Anaerobic pathway = pyruvate to lactate = 2ATP (Cori cycle)
  • Aerobic pathway = conversion of pyruvate 3C into Acetyl coA 2C --> (Krebs cycle)
  • (2) Gluconeogenesis (production of glucose from other molecules)
  • In case dietary glucose runs out - takes place mainly in the liver.
  • Pyruvate --> Oxaceletate (C4) at the cost of 1 ATP. (NET cost to get to glucose 6ATP (which can yield 34ATP)
  • Some organs (heart, brain) rely on glucose for ATP
  • Has many potential substrates:
  • Lactate
  • Pyruvate
  • Glycerol (fats)
  • Amino acids (alanine and glutamate)
  • CAC-intermediates
  • Is stimulated by glucagon
  • Is inhibited by biguanides (metformin)
  • (3) Glycogenesis
  • Into Glycogen (storage)
  • when glucose and ATP present in high amounts - stored as glucose-6-phosphate.
  • (4) Glycogenolysis
  • out of Glycogen (from storage)
  • provides a source of energy that can be mobalised instantly.
  • The store will exhausted in 3-4 hours.

Krebs cycle

  • Acetyl-CoA (2C) joins Oxaloacetate (4C) to form Citrate (C6)
  • Citrate (C6) --> alpha-ketaglutamate (C5) --> Succinate (C4) --> Oxaloacetate (C4)
  • output = 1 ATP + 3 NADH + 1 FADH2
  • For each molecule of glucose = 34 ATP


During the Digestive process which starts in the mouth with mastication, complex sugars are broken down into simple sugars that can be transported across cell walls and used to make energy in the form of ATP.

The simple sugar glucose is the body's most readily available energy source and can by used by all cells.
question3: Starvation - what stores does a 70kg male possess? if there is no energy intake how does the body adapt?
contents3:
Stores: Energy stored as carbohydrate, protein and triglycerides.

  • 1600kcal as glycogen.
  • 24,000kcal in mobilisable protein
  • 135,000kcal in triglycerides.


A lot of energy is stored in Triglycerides; however,

Fatty acids cannot be converted into glucose to supply the brain or red cells because acetyl-CoA cannot be converted into pyruvate.

The only other source of glucose available is amino acids derived from protein breakdown - ie, muscle breakdown. (2nd priority maintaining muscle mass/proteins)

Consequently, the body shifts its primary fuel source from glucose to fatty acids and ketones.
question4: What adaptions occur during the first 24 hours of starvation?  What adaptions after 72 hours?  What adaptions at several weeks?
contents4:
24 hours

  • glucose falls - insulin falls - counter-regulatory hormone glucagon increases
  • glucagon --> mobilisation of:
  • triglycerides in fats
  • gluconeogenesis in liver
  • concentrations of Acetyl-CoA, Citrate increase - fall in glycolysis.
  • muscle uptake of glucose falls (low insulin) muscle also shifts to fatty acid as fuel

72 hours:

  • most important metabolic change is the hepatic production of large amounts of ketone bodies (acetoacetate and 3-hydroxybutarate) from Acetyl-CoA.
  • this occurs because gluconeogenesis depletes the supply of Oxaloecetate, which is essential for Acetyl-CoA to enter the Krebs cycle.
  • Instead the acetyl-CoA is used for Ketogenesis.
  • brain can use acetoacetate (ketone bodies) for 30% of its energy requirements,

Several weeks:

  • Ketones now become the major fuel source for the brain (>70%)
  • The effective conversion of fatty acids into ketones by the liver and their subsequent use by the brain markedly diminishes the need for glucose and therefore reduces muscle breakdonw.
  • The duration of starvation compatible with life is determines by the size of the triacylglycerol stores.
